race.name: Wild Horse Gravel
race.tagline: Western Colorado high desert gravel in De Beque.

climate.description: High desert conditions with variable weather. Heat possible depending on season.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through western Colorado high desert. Moderate elevation with desert and canyon scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Small grassroots western Colorado event. Remote high desert setting but very limited infrastructure.

biased_opinion.summary: Wild Horse Gravel is a small grassroots gravel race in western Colorado's high desert. De Beque is a small remote town with minimal amenities. The high desert scenery is beautiful and unique, but it's a tiny field with basic organization. It's an honest local event for hardy western Colorado cyclists who want an affordable desert gravel ride.
weaknesses: Small field with no competitive depth
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A small local gravel race in remote western Colorado high desert. Perfect for locals or those seeking a unique desert gravel experience. Not worth the long drive for most riders unless you're combining with western Colorado tourism.

final_verdict.one_liner: Small grassroots western Colorado high desert ride with remote location.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Only if you're in western Colorado or seeking unique desert gravel. Not worth the long drive for the race alone.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Colorado events: Leadville 100, Steamboat Gravel. For similar desert vibes: other western desert events.

logistics.airport: Grand Junction (GJT) 45 min, or Denver (DEN) 2.5 hours
logistics.lodging_strategy: De Beque has very limited lodging. Look for nearby towns or camping.
logistics.food: Small town with minimal dining. Bring your own.
logistics.camping: camping setup Friday 5:00pm-9:00pm at High Lonesome Ranch

history.origin_story: Grassroots gravel event in western Colorado high desert.

course_description.character: High desert gravel through canyons and desert terrain.
course_description.signature_challenge: High desert terrain and remote location.

non_negotiables.why: High desert means intense sun exposure and potential heat.
Remote location and minimal support mean managing your own nutrition and mechanicals.

topics.fueling: Hydration and nutrition in dry conditions

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 62 miles of western Colorado high desert gravel.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Small grassroots event in remote De Beque.

logistics.explanation: Ryan Sederquist describes a 'horse-led 10-mile neutral rideout' before the timed 55-mile course, creating unique logistical complexity. Friday packet pickup happens at De Beque Community Center while racing starts at High Lonesome Ranch 25 miles away. Free camping at the ranch helps, but the scattered venues between tiny De Beque and remote ranch locations require careful planning.

length.explanation: Jack Luke positioned himself strategically early, noting 'I lined up at the front of the third wave and immediately started making up ground on the second wave.' The 65-mile distance with neutralized start allows tactical racing without crushing weekend warriors. Elite riders can race hard while recreational cyclists enjoy the Western Colorado scenery over manageable distance. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar. As Jack Luke puts it: "The beating hot sun definitely took its toll on my pasty white complexion along this section and I was chugging away more water than probably necessary."

technicality.explanation: Course features '85% gravel/dirt roads, 10% doubletrack, 5% paved' with moderate technical challenge. Jack Luke noted 'the tricky nature of some of the descents. They were steep and rutted' but emphasized there was 'no time clock running between segments.' The terrain demands attention without requiring advanced mountain bike skills. Less technical than The Mid South. As Jack Luke puts it: "The following 40km was a blur of wild descents, punchy climbs and some of the most impressive landscapes I have ever ridden."

elevation.explanation: Ryan Sederquist climbed to 'the course's high point of 8,200 feet' after gaining '1,800 vertical feet' in 45 minutes during one climb section. JOM's bike with '48/32 chainring pairing and an 11-32 cassette' was 'perfect for much of the course, except the really steep stuff.' The 5,500 feet of climbing delivers substantial challenge through punchy Western Colorado terrain. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds. As Jack Luke puts it: "The following 40km was a blur of wild descents, punchy climbs and some of the most impressive landscapes I have ever ridden."

climate.explanation: Jack Luke experienced 'temperature was brisk in the low 50's Fahrenheit, but the sun's rays would warm the day to the low 70's Fahrenheit' in May 2019. Ryan Sederquist forgot sunscreen on a warm 2022 day, while 2023 brought rain that transformed trails to mud. High desert conditions create variable weather but May timing avoids extreme heat or cold. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL. As Jack Luke puts it: "The beating hot sun definitely took its toll on my pasty white complexion along this section and I was chugging away more water than probably necessary."

altitude.explanation: The course reaches 8,200 feet at its high point, with most riding between 5,000-7,000 feet elevation. Jack Luke, coming from sea level, noted feeling 'my legs from Friday's ride, along with the altitude' during warmup. The Western Colorado high desert elevation affects performance without being debilitating for most riders accustomed to moderate altitude. Similar altitude considerations to Grinduro.

adventure.explanation: High desert Western Slope Colorado through the Valley of the Goblins and around Horse Mountain Range delivers backcountry scenery. High Lonesome Ranch venue adds authentic Western atmosphere beyond typical suburban gravel fare. The terrain and location provide real adventure factor, even if the racing itself isn't destination-level.

prestige.explanation: Strambecco calls it the 'Best Gravel Cycling Race in Colorado and Rockies,' which tells you everything about how desperate cycling media gets for content. Zero pro field data, no notable past winners mentioned, and it's organized by Gemini Adventures—not household names. The gravel world hasn't heard of this one, and there's a reason for that.

race_quality.explanation: The course data is a mess—official sources can't decide if it's 62 or 65 miles, or whether you're climbing 3500 or 5500 feet. Mixed terrain through the Horse Mountain Range sounds promising, but when organizers can't nail down basic metrics, it screams small-time operation. At least they promise 'a little bit of everything,' which usually means mediocre everything.

experience.explanation: The event features 'hay bale awards podium' and 'country music' with camping at High Lonesome Ranch creating Western atmosphere. However, john_with_a_camera withdrew, complaining 'The day starts at like 9:30, and it goes until a 3 PM awards ceremony' and noting excessive commercialization. The ranch setting and cowboy theme work, but execution feels drawn-out for some participants.

community.explanation: Free camping at High Lonesome Ranch, campfires, and live music create decent weekend vibes for the gravel family crowd. Friday shakeout rides and free bike tech from Roan Creek Bikeworks shows they're thinking about rider needs. It's part of the Ride Collective Series, so you get that small regional scene energy—nothing flashy, but people show up and have a good time.

field_depth.explanation: While Ryan Sederquist mentions racing with 'former Olympians, gravel pros,' the field lacks documented competitive depth. Elite riders participate but treat it as training rather than destination racing. Kim, a 53-year-old Dirty Kanza veteran, represents the experienced amateur demographic that forms the race's competitive core rather than professional athletes. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Miles 55-65 puts it: "A thrilling and technical descent back to the valley. Expect loose corners and fast straightaways."

value.explanation: $105 early bird gets you aid stations, post-race food, awards, camping, live music, and a full weekend of activities at High Lonesome Ranch. That's solid bang for your buck compared to the $200+ robbery most gravel races pull these days. Free bike tech and a proper Western Slope weekend experience make this one of the better deals in Colorado, even if the racing isn't elite.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-90. Free camping at High Lonesome Ranch eliminates major lodging costs, while De Beque's location 25 miles from Grand Junction provides regional airport access. On-site food trucks and ranch facilities keep meal costs reasonable. JOM noted extensive hospitality including winery visits and coffee shop stops during media rides, suggesting organizers work to control participant expenses beyond entry fees. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Wild Horse Gravel gravel race De Beque

videos.title: 2019 Wild Horse Gravel - A Secret Stash of High Desert Gravel! - De Beque, Colorado
videos.description:
"Wild Horse Gravel showcases the unique high desertscape of the Western Slope. Hosted on the luxury High Lonesome Ranch, riders will be treated to a country cook-out, campfire, cabins, camping – or glamping – and the best local music. In short, there will be a Colorado country party to accompany the ride." - Roll Massif

"In addition to being hidden well, well off the beaten path, The High Lonesome Ranch and its surrounding area isn’t open to riding year-round, so participants benefit from exclusive access to this secret stash of wild-west gravel. You’ll only be disappointed if you were hoping for a bunch of auto traffic on the route."

The new for 2019 Wild Horse Gravel had two routes to choose from; an out and back 70+ miler from The High Lonesome Ranch to De Beque, Colorado, or a shorter loop that took in De Beque and headed the short way to The High Lonesome Ranch. Either way, riders were guaranteed a good time with mindblowing scenery.

Event by Roll Massif: http://rollmassif.com
The HIgh Lonesome Ranch: http://thehighlonesomeranch.com

Amazon Affiliation Link:
No cost to you, but every purchase made helps keep Gravel Cyclist up and running! - https://www.amazon.com/?&_encoding=UTF8&tag=gravelcyclist-20&linkCode=ur2&linkId=6b862b6af640d29360e2af2a5f17ddc6&camp=1789&creative=9325

Web: http://GravelCyclist.com
Facebook: http://facebook.com/GravelCyclist
Instagram - http://Instagram/GravelCyclist
Twitter - http://twitter.com/GravelCyclist
Vimeo - http://vimeo.com/GravelCyclist
tags: 2019 wild horse gravel de beque colorado

videos.title: FoCo Fondo gravel race course preview 2023
videos.description:
Dog Dare. Double Dog Dare. Or Triple Dog Dare?!

FoCo Fondo in Fort Collins, Colorado is a gravel race and ride on July 23, 2023. There are four routes, from the 12-mile Safe Routes to School family ride up to the 118-mile Triple Dog Dare Route where $9,000 of prize money is on the line.

Whitney and Zack Allison give us a tour of what's new and cool on the Triple Dog Route for 2023, plus we take a quick tour of New Belgium Brewery, host venue for FoCo Fondo on the northeast corner of Fort Collins.

More info and registration at: https://www.focofondo.com/

---
The Ride is supported in 2023 by:

Castelli clothing: https://www.castelli-cycling.com
Giro helmets: https://www.giro.com
Feedback Sports stands & tools: https://www.feedbacksports.com

videos.title: New Colorado Summer of Gravel series highlights the state's diverse topography
videos.description:
Colorado has an abundance of gravel race riches this season, including a new series of four great races called the Colorado Summer of Gravel. This new series runs mid-May through July and includes CO2UT in the desert of western Colorado, Telluride Gravel Race in the mountainous south, Ned Gravel high up in central Colorado, and FoCo Fondo to the north in Fort Collins. 

Combined, it’s quite the diverse tour of Colorado’s varied topography. 

Check out the details:
www.coloradosummerofgravel.com/

2023 Colorado Gravel Races (not a complete list):
Old Man Winter Rally February 5 - Lyons https://www.oldmanwinterrally.com/
CO2UT Desert Gravel Race May 14 - Fruita (Colorado Summer of Gravel) https://www.desertgravel.com/
Wild Horse Gravel May 20 - De Beque https://events.outsideonline.com/wildhorse/
Weld County Grinder May 20 - Nunn https://www.facebook.com/groups/448024803435353
Mad Gravel May 29 - Elbert https://rattlerracing.com/event/madgravel/
Telluride Gravel Race June 10 - Telluride (Colorado Summer of Gravel) https://telluridegravelrace.com/
Pony Xpress Gravel 160 June 17 - Trinidad http://coloradogravelgrinderchampionship.com/pony-xpress/the-race
Bighorn Gravel June 25 - Gypsum https://www.bighorngravel.com/
Ned Gravel July 8 - Nederland (Colorado Summer of Gravel) https://www.nedgravel.com/
Crooked Gravel July 22 - Winter Park https://events.outsideonline.com/crookedgravel/
Foco Fondo July 23 - Fort Collins (Colorado Summer of Gravel) https://www.focofondo.com/
SBT GRVL August 20 - Steamboat Springs https://www.sbtgrvl.com/
Gunni Grinder September 9 - Gunnison https://www.thegunnigrinder.com/
Salida 76 September 16 - Salida https://www.salida76.com/
High Plains Drifter September 22 - Greeley https://www.facebook.com/groups/1082760892162809
Gravel Locos September 30 - Pueblo https://www.gravellocos.bike/pueblo
Rad Dirt Fest September 30 - Trinidad https://www.theraddirt.com/

--

The Ride is supported in 2023 by 
Castelli clothing: castelli-cycling.com
Giro helmets: giro.com
Feedback Sports stands & tools: feedbacksports.com

riches this year including a new series
called the colorado summer of gravel
this new series runs mid-may through
July and includes CO2 UT in the desert
of Western Colorado the Telluride gravel
race in the mountainous South Ned gravel
high up in central Colorado just up the
hill from my home in Boulder and foco
Fondo to the North in Fort Collins

quotes.text: Conditions were loose and rutted in places requiring a careful choice of one's line. The segment saved the best for last with a very steep climb finishing proceedings followed by another steep hill to reach the neutral water station.

Barring the scenery of the high desert you will likely encounter all manner of critters including cows and wild horses. Wild Horse scramble isn't a race rather a ride although there are two possible timed segments.
